if they are registered in the Manifest (and if the app targets the API
level). This change prepares for this behavior change, and also makes
MAXS Transport XMPP more resource friendly on older Android devices in
case the Transport is not running (active).

title: transport-xmpp: Fix reconnecting 'deadlock'
message:
transport-xmpp: Fix reconnecting 'deadlock'

XMPPService could get into a state where it continuesly tries to
reconnect while simulatenously blocking the main thread. But this also
prevents SmackAndroid from receiving ConnectivityChange notifications
and calling Resolver.refresh() which leads to unuseable DNS server
information. Therefore every connection attempt failes because Smack
is unable to resolve the domain. The reconnect loop starts again,
usually because there is another intent like SET_STATUS in the queue,
and the main thread is still blocked.

title: transport-xmpp: Save password on Activity unfocus
message:
transport-xmpp: Save password on Activity unfocus

Many users currently run into the pitfall that they enter their JID, the
devices JID and the devices password and hit the back button, while the
password EditText is still focused. This means that EditTextWatcher's
onFocusChange() did not run and the password has not been saved to the
SharedPreferences.

We know save whatever currently is entered as password when the Activity
loses focus by using the onPause() method.

Note that the JID EditFields are still affected by the problem but
- we have to verify the JIDs for correctness
- and they appear visually before the password EditText
so this approach is not feasible for the JID EditFields.

title: module-smsnotify: Set priority to 999 for receiver
message:
module-smsnotify: Set priority to 999 for receiver

Set the priority for the SMS_RECEIVED broadcast receiver to 999. The old
XML date was incorrect, as the priority attribute was part of the action
element instead of the intent-filter element. And 1010 was an incorrect
value anyways, since the maximum is 999 as per the updated documentation
[1].

Also SMS_RECEIVED broadcasts are non-abortable, at least as of Android
4.4 [2]. This means that it shouldn't matter at which priority the
receiver runs. But first tests with SMS enabled Hangouts 2.0 showed that
the Receiver was only run with a priority of 999 and 500, but not 1.

Footnotes:
[1]  http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/manifest/intent-filter-element.html

[2]  http://developer.android.com/about/versions/android-4.4.html#SMS
